CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of the first - instance court . The court considered that , regardless of ORG contention , the applicant had to receive a custodial sentence under the penal law . It was noted that ORG had an obligation to organise the execution of custodial sentences .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG of the ORG of ORG ( PERSON tiesas ORG departaments ) dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on points of law ; the applicant ’s conviction took effect . The ORG established that the sentence imposed on the applicant was the minimum sentence provided for in law for the type of offence ; a more lenient sentence ( than that provided for in law ) was impossible since the applicant had reoffended . The ORG noted that a court could release a prisoner under section DATE , paragraph CARDINAL of LAW if he or she had fallen ill with a severe and incurable illness after the pronouncement of the judgment . The applicant , however , had been suffering from an incurable illness since long before his conviction . Moreover , his illness had not prevented him from committing an especially serious offence . The ORG pointed out that under section CARDINAL of the LAW emergency medical care was available to detainees , if necessary in a civil setting . ORG was under an obligation to organise the execution of custodial sentences ; if such execution became impossible , section CARDINAL of the Law of Criminal Procedure provided for the possibility of release on health grounds . This could only be decided by a judge overseeing matters of execution of custodial sentences , after the conviction had taken effect .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON ) , in force since DATE , if a convicted person has fallen ill with a severe and incurable illness after the pronouncement of a judgment , a court may release that person from serving the remainder of the sentence .

CARDINAL . According to section QUANTITY of LAW ( ORG izpildes kodekss ) , if a convicted person has fallen ill with a severe and incurable illness owing to which he or she is unable to serve the remainder of his or her sentence , the relevant penal institution has to order a medical examination and , on the basis of the results , make an application for release to the appropriate court .

CARDINAL . The relevant part of section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of LAW ( GPE likums ) , in force since DATE , provides that a judge may release a convicted person from serving the remainder of his or her sentence if that person has fallen ill while serving the sentence , taking into account the personality of the convicted person , the nature of the crime , and other circumstances . Before the entry into force of LAW , the relevant provision was contained in LAW kodekss ) .
